text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.71.13, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, Technical Technical Advice Requests and Requests for Relief under IRC section 7805(b).
MATERIAL CHANGES

Enhanced IRM 4.71.13.1, Program, Scope and Objectives, and the subsections thereunder, by adding more information on the internal controls regulating EP Examinations. Reorganized material for improved readability and uniformity with other EP Examination IRMs.
IRM
, Safeguarding Personally Identiﬁable Information, was added to comply with the December

, Internal Guidance Memorandum (IGM) from the Director, Identity and Records Protection Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure, entitled Social Security Number Elimination and Reduction (SSN ER). This section augments compliance with the May
Memorandum (M-

) issued by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) entitled Safeguarding Against and Responding to the Breach of Personally Identiﬁable Information to the Heads of Executive Departments and Agencies.

IRM 4.71.13.1.7, Safeguarding Personally Identiﬁable Information, was added to comply with the December 20, 2016, Internal Guidance Memorandum (IGM) from the Director, Identity and Records Protection Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure, entitled Social Security Number Elimination and Reduction (SSN ER). This section augments compliance with the May 22, 2007 Memorandum (M-07-16) issued by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) entitled Safeguarding Against and Responding to the Breach of Personally Identiﬁable Information to the Heads of Executive
references as needed for the Revenue Procedures listed in the ﬁrst column of the table with the Revenue Procedures they were superseded by in the second column.
Replaced Rev. Proc. Updated Rev. Proc 2018-1 2019-1 2018-2 2019-2 2018-4 2019-4

Updated IRM section 4.71.13.4.1, Mandatory Technical Advice, to comply with the revised Section 3.04 of Revenue Procedure 2019-2, by deleting collectively bargained plans from the list of issues required to be submitted for a Technical Advice Memorandum (TAM).
Removed reference to IRM 1.2.13.1.25 due to the pending obsolescence of the IRM.

) Audience: This IRM provides procedures for agents, managers, and support staff in EP Examinations. (
) Program Owner: Director, EP Examinations sets the program for the EP amination program. (
) Program Authority: EP Examinations’ authority to conduct examinations, resolve issues and determine tax liability is derived from Title

This IRM section is authored by EP Mandatory Review. For questions, informa- tion or suggestions, contact the manager of EP Mandatory Review
EP Examinations is the division designated to determine if a retirement plan is qualiﬁed under IRC 401, and the underlying regulations, and thus, exempt from
EP Examinations’ primary objective is regulatory, emphasizing continued ﬁcation of employee beneﬁt plans EP selects and examines returns to:
Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws on plan qualiﬁcation. Determine qualiﬁed plans’ extent of compliance and the causes of non
compliance with the tax laws. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation require
ments in operation.

a. Given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting information, and opinions. b. To use professional judgement according to auditing standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to the correct tax liability. c. To exercise this authority to obtain the greatest number of tax tion agreements without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those determinations and to dispose of tax differences at the lowest level. ) See the Area Counsel Geographic Coverage List for the office covering taxpayer’s location and the Area Counsel Office Listing for Counsel contact information. (
) Generally, an opinion from Area Counsel is conﬁned to the speciﬁc facts circumstances of a case. You shouldn’t apply the opinion to other cases without contacting Counsel. (
) Whenever you want to pursue the six year statute of limitations (SOL) for case, you must obtain written approval from Area Counsel. Keep a copy of written response in the case ﬁle. (
) Reviewers in Mandatory Review and Special Review help agents and managers with technical and procedural issues. (

(EP Examination c. Has questions about a special exam project coordinated by a Mandatory Review.

, Form
or potential fraud issues. (
) Agents and managers may get help on technical issues through the TE/GE Knowledge Management Portal (K-Net). (

) Agents should attempt to resolve technical and procedural issues at the level before requesting assistance. Ask senior agents and the group for help before you contact Mandatory Review or Special Review. (
) Group managers may contact the Manager, Mandatory Review or the Manager, Special Review to ask a reviewer to give a presentation of a topic of interest at a group meeting. (
) These technical advice (tech advice) procedures follow Rev. Proc.

guidelines and aid agents when requesting a TAM from the TE/GE Office of Associate Chief Counsel (Associate Chief Counsel) for help on any technical or procedural question that develops during your EP exam. ) Tech advice is deﬁned as written advice prepared by Associate Chief as to: a. The interpretation and proper application of tax law, tax treaties, tions, revenue rulings, notices or other published precedents. b. A speciﬁc set of facts connected to the examination of a taxpayer’s return, consideration of a taxpayer’s claim for refund or credit. c. Any other matter under EP Examinations’ jurisdiction. (

) Request a TAM when the application of the law to the facts involved in your exam is unclear. The question must be on “the interpretation and proper cation of tax laws, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, notices, or precedents to a speciﬁc set of facts that concerns the treatment of an item period under examination.” (
) Contact the Area Counsel office responsible for the state in which the is located before you request a TAM. See IRM
), Assistance Area Counsel. Note: You must receive Area Counsel’s support before proceed with a TAM. As discussed below, Area Counsel will help you with the TAM request sion. (

contacting Area Counsel. After obtaining Area Counsel’s approval to request a TAM, the group must obtain written approval (email approval will suffice) from his/her Area Manager and the Director, EP Examinations before submitting the formal request. If the Area Manager and the Director, EP Examinations agree that a TAM should be pursued, a Pre-Submission Conference must be held with Chief Counsel, see IRM
, Pre-submission Conference. If Associate Chief Counsel agrees during the Pre-Submission Conference a TAM should be requested, the agent prepares Form

with explaining the: a. Facts and the issues surrounding the TAM request b. Applicable law and arguments in support of the position(s) of the IRS the issue or issues c. Applicable law and arguments in support of the position(s) of the taxpayer on the issue or issues Note: Generally, each issue should be presented separately using the traditional facts, law, government’s position, taxpayer’s position conclusion format. ) The taxpayer has no authority to bar an internal decision to seek technical advice. However, agents, group managers, and Area Managers may consider any taxpayer objections. (

) The taxpayer has ﬁve calendar days to respond to the Technical Advice Notiﬁ- cation. If the taxpayer requests additional time: a. The taxpayer must make a written request to extend the ﬁve day period before the period expires. The request must include the speciﬁc reasons justifying the extended time requested and a written signature of a duly authorized individual on behalf of the taxpayer. b. Upon receipt of the written request to extend the ﬁve day period, the agent immediately reviews the request and sends it to his/her group manager with a recommendation.

The taxpayer must make a written request to extend the ﬁve day period before the period expires. The request must include the speciﬁc reasons justifying the extended time requested and a written signature of a duly authorized individual on behalf of the taxpayer. Upon receipt of the written request to extend the ﬁve day period, the agent immediately reviews the request and sends it to his/her group manager with a recommendation.

tion, he/she should acknowledge agreement in writing. Include the taxpayer’s letter in the TAM request package. b. Disagrees with the agent’s statement of issues and facts in the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation, he/she should identify each point of disagreement and state the reasons for disagreement in writing. The taxpayer’s written statement should respond completely to the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation and must include a written signature of a duly authorized individual on behalf of the taxpayer.
Note: The agent and taxpayer have 10 calendar days to resolve disagreements. See section 7.06 of Rev. Proc. 2019-2..

Agent: If you receive a written statement from the taxpayer, evaluate all documents and: a. Disagree with the taxpayer’s statements of issues and facts, respond with a written notice of disagreement to the taxpayer. This response is required even if we determine a TAM request is unwarranted. b. Determine a TAM is warranted/unwarranted, prepare a written of the issues, speciﬁcally for the group manager and the Area explaining why the taxpayer’s request for a TAM should be approved denied. c. Immediately fax or email the summary and a copy of the taxpayer’s written statement to your manager. Group manager: Upon receipt, immediately forward the agent’s summary a copy of the taxpayer’s written statement with your recommendation to the Area Manager. The Area Manager: a. May direct the manner and the extent of additional documentation needed for approval. b. May deny a taxpayer initiated request for a TAM based on material agreement over issues and/or facts. c. May approve the taxpayer’s request for a TAM, then solicit the EP Examinations approval. d. Will inform the group manager in writing when he/she and the EP Examinations both approve the TAM. The formal TAM request includes the taxpayer’s written statement and all statements and correspondence between the agent and the taxpayer in nection with any disagreement over issues and facts. Agent: If the Area Manager denies the taxpayer’s request for a TAM, inform the taxpayer in writing. The taxpayer may appeal IRS’s decision to deny the taxpayer’s TAM by submitting to the agent, within

calendar days after being notiﬁed the request was denied, a written statement of the reasons why the matter be referred to Associate Chief Counsel. The statement should include a de- scription of all pertinent facts (including any facts in dispute); a statement of the issue that the taxpayer would like to have addressed; a discussion of

Disagree with the taxpayer’s statements of issues and facts, respond with a written notice of disagreement to the taxpayer. This response is required even if we determine a TAM request is unwarranted. Determine a TAM is warranted/unwarranted, prepare a written summary of the issues, speciﬁcally for the group manager and the Area Manager, explaining why the taxpayer’s request for a TAM should be approved or denied. Immediately fax or email the summary and a copy of the taxpayer’s written statement to your manager.
The taxpayer may appeal IRS’s decision to deny the taxpayer’s TAM request by submitting to the agent, within

calendar days after being notiﬁed the request was denied, a written statement of the reasons why the matter should be referred to Associate Chief Counsel. The statement should include a de- scription of all pertinent facts (including any facts in dispute); a statement of the issue that the taxpayer would like to have addressed; a discussion of any
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
relevant statutory, regulatory, or administrative provisions, tax treaties, case law, or other authority; and an explanation of the taxpayer’s position and the need for technical advice.
Note: Any extensions of the 30-day period must be requested in writing and approved by the Director, EP Examinations.

Group manager: Immediately forward the taxpayer’s written request appealing the decision to deny the TAM request, along with the ﬁeld office’s statement to why the issue shouldn’t be referred to Associate Chief Counsel for technical advice, to the Director, EP Examinations. Agent: If the Director, EP Examinations: a. Agrees with the taxpayer that a TAM should be requested, inform the taxpayer of the decision and submit the TAM request per IRM

, Initiating A Request For Technical Advice. b. Determines that a TAM is not warranted, inform the taxpayer in writing of the denial of the request and the reasons for the denial. If the taxpayer disagrees with the Director, EP Examinations’ decision to deny the TAM request, the taxpayer may request a review by the Commissioner, TE/GE.
Note: The Commissioner, TE/GE has 45 days to deliver a ﬁnal decision per section 5.04 of Rev. Proc. 2019-2.
After Area Counsel, the Area Manager and the Director, EP Examinations approve the TAM request, a pre-submission conference is scheduled with the:
The legal analysis provided in the parties’ statements should be sufficient to enable Counsel to be reasonably informed about the subject matter.

supporting authorities, and any other background information that the parties believe would facilitate Associate Chief Counsel’s understanding of the issues to be discussed during the conference.

to be discussed during the conference. Note: The taxpayer’s failure to provide a statement of pertinent issues and facts shouldn’t unduly delay the scheduling of the pre-submission conference. If the taxpayer doesn’t provide it within a reasonable period of time, you may schedule the conference without the statements. (

) Agent: Email the following items to the Area Counsel attorney: a. A statement of issues that the parties would like to discuss. b. A statement of pertinent facts. c. A statement of the facts in dispute, if any. d. Any legal analysis, authorities or background documents that could the attorney understand the issues. (This doesn’t have to be fully developed as there will be an analysis that will ultimately accompany formal request for a TAM). e. The taxpayer’s statement of pertinent facts and issues f. mailbox, requesting a submission conference. Note: The factual information should cover all collateral issues for which EP nations is seeking tech. advice from Associate Chief Counsel.

) The pre-submission conference (likely held by telephone) should be held
calendar days after the agent is contacted. (
) Associate Chief Counsel: arrange the pre-submission conference call and notify all parties involved of the date, time and conference call number. (

Every request for tech. advice must include a description of the facts, issues, applicable law, and arguments supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the IRS’s position on the issues.

applicable law, and arguments supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the IRS’s position on the issues. a. If the taxpayer and the ﬁeld office disagree about ultimate ﬁndings of fact or about the relevance of facts, include all of the facts with an explana
tion highlighting the areas of disagreement. b. Include in the memo, an explanation of the taxpayer’s position. This ex
planation must include a discussion of any relevant statutory provisions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue proce

dures, notices, and any other authority supporting the taxpayer’s position. c. Include in the memo, a similar explanation of the position of the IRS. This explanation must include a discussion of any relevant statutory provi

sions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and any other authority supporting the IRS position. d. Both the IRS and the taxpayer should comment on any existing or pending legislation, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, or court decisions contrary to their respective positions. e. If either party determines that there are no authorities conﬂicting their position, that statement should be noted in the memo. The ﬁeld office submits the request for tech. advice.

) If Associate Chief Counsel determines that the TAM request package is deﬁcient, the agent, the Area Counsel attorney and the Associate Chief Counsel attorney will work together to obtain the necessary information. If issue can’t be resolved within

days after receipt, Associate Chief Counsel will: a. Contact the agent and/or Area Counsel to discuss any procedural and substantive issues in the case. b. Notify the agent whether any matters have been referred to another Associate Chief Counsel attorney for assistance. (
) When Associate Chief Counsel is ready to issue the TAM, they’ll their conclusions and reasoning to Area Counsel. Area Counsel may discuss any disagreements. (

) If Associate Chief Counsel proposes an adverse TAM and the taxpayer has waived its right to a conference, then they’ll inform the taxpayer of the time and place of the conference. a. The agent and his/her group manager will be given the opportunity to participate in that conference. b. ) If the taxpayer submits additional information after the conference, the must either provide Associate Chief Counsel with comments on the information or notate to Associate Chief Counsel that the agent has no comments. (

) Before issuing the ﬁnal TAM, Associate Chief Counsel will issue a TAM to the agent and to Area Counsel. a. ) Associate Chief Counsel’s reply to a TAM request is in two parts. Each part identiﬁes the taxpayer by name, address, identiﬁcation number and year or years involved. (

) The ﬁrst part of the reply is a transmittal memorandum. a. The transmittal memorandum, which is sent with the technical advice memorandum, should never be released to the taxpayer. b. (07-12-2019) Conclusion of the When Technical Advice Is Received
The procedures for requesting relief under 7805(b) for plans under examination changed effective January 2, 2018, with the issuance of Rev. Proc. 2018-4.
Technical Assistance, Technical Advice Requests and Requests for Relief under IRC section 7805(b) 4.71.13 page 19
a. Section
of Rev. Proc.
provides,“ In order for a petitioner be deemed to have exhausted administrative remedies within the with respect to §
(b), an applicant must submit a request for under §
(b) to the Service in accordance with the procedures in section
of this revenue procedure. A request for relief under §
(b) must be submitted to the agent or specialist assigned to the case.” b. Section
provides, “A request for relief under §
(b) must be writing and must be submitted to the agent or specialist assigned to case. The request for relief under §

(b) must be submitted issuance of the ﬁnal adverse determination letter”. A request for relief can occur only when the plan has a determination letter and the agent discovers the plan document contains faulty language or include required language. In other words, the determination letter was in error. A taxpayer’s request for retroactive relief must be in writing and submitted the agent prior to Mandatory Review issuing the ﬁnal revocation letter.

A request for relief can occur only when the plan has a determination letter and the agent discovers the plan document contains faulty language or fails to include required language. In other words, the determination letter was issued in error.
A taxpayer’s request for retroactive relief must be in writing and submitted to the agent prior to Mandatory Review issuing the ﬁnal revocation letter.

Without 7805(b) relief, revocation is retroactive. Generally, the revoca- tion will be retroactive to the effective date of the plan, to the effective date of the plan provision containing the faulty language or, if later, to the effective date of the required omitted language. Retroactivity is based on when the language was effective.
